title.narrative: Sierra Leone – GIZ- Health Systems Strengthening

description.narrative: Despite rising allocations on healthcare and its high political importance, key health indicators such as maternal and child mortality have not improved significantly. The electronic disease surveillance and response system is introduced nationwide. The many developed plans, strategies, policy guidelines, curricula and databases for health information systems and human resources management do not function appropriately. Thus, the healthcare system is not yet optimally aligned to the health needs of the population (core problem). This project therefore aims at providing technical assistance to improve the quality of health services through human resource development, more efficient and needs-based decentralized management of the health system and the institutionalization of the reporting and response system for infectious diseases with epidemic potential.

Staff of the Directorate for Policy, Planning and Information of the MOHS; staff of the district county and District Health Management Team of two districts: Kambia and Kailahun. 18 Health Centres Target group is the population of Kambia and Kailahun and, to a lesser extent, the total population of Sierra Leone as well as the population of the neighboring communities of Liberia and Guinea. Intermediaries to reach these target groups are female and male health professionals of the district health management teams (DHMTs) in Kambia and Kailahun. Further intermediaries are the staff in the health institutions of the two districts and at the community level, District Councils, community members and staff for agriculture, livestock breeding and environmental protection at the district level. At the national level, employees of the Ministry of Health and its directorates, as well as employees of the national authorities for agriculture, livestock and environmental protection, are to be mentioned as target group.

The objective is defined as: The healthcare system in selected districts in Sierra Leone, including sufficient staffing, is better adapted to the health needs of the population. 1) The proportion of correctly collected data of the Sierra Leonean health indicators from the national Health Information System (District Health Information System 2, DHIS-2) increased from 0% to 70% in Kambia and Kailahun. 2) Quarterly updated Action Plan Management Matrices (Action Plan Management Matrix, APMM) are present in Kambia and Kailahun.
